description: Kali Linux is an advanced, versatile penetration testing platform and has dozens and dozens of tools complied into it, making it a very powerful, yet highly customizable platform. These episodes will teach you how to install Kali Linux, and how to use Kali Linux to test the security of a network. You will learn how to effectively perform a penetration test using the various tools found in Kali Linux.
descriptionMD: Kali Linux is an advanced, versatile penetration testing platform and has dozens and dozens of tools complied into it, making it a very powerful, yet highly customizable platform. These episodes will teach you how to install Kali Linux, and how to use Kali Linux to test the security of a network. You will learn how to effectively perform a penetration test using the various tools found in Kali Linux.
name: Kali Linux (2017)
subtitle: Configuration of Kali Linux

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what Kali Linux is, a brief history of Kali Linux, how it is 'Debian' derived, best usues of Kali Linux, installation options, the requirements to run it, supported platforms, and features of Kali Linux.
episodes.title: History of Kali Linux
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:02.451
Welcome on ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.451 --> 00:00:06.546
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.546 --> 00:00:08.344
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.344 --> 00:00:12.340
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.340 --> 00:00:13.420
>> Hello again, thank you for

6
00:00:13.420 --> 00:00:17.475
joining us on ITProTV,
where we help you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:17.475 --> 00:00:22.563
I'm your host Zach Memos,
as we begin a new series, Kali Linux.

8
00:00:22.563 --> 00:00:25.434
And today, we're gonna learn a little
bit about the history of Kali Linux.

9
00:00:25.434 --> 00:00:29.223
And the person bringing us
that information is Kalima!

10
00:00:29.223 --> 00:00:31.052
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's Mike Roderick, right over here.

11
00:00:31.052 --> 00:00:32.568
>> Hey, Zack.

12
00:00:32.568 --> 00:00:33.810
>> Hey, Mike.

13
00:00:33.810 --> 00:00:38.642
>> Yeah, we're gonna be taking a look at
Kali Linux in this next several episodes,

14
00:00:38.642 --> 00:00:41.040
as we go through this series.

15
00:00:41.040 --> 00:00:44.148
And is all good things, we wanna start, we
need to know where we came from in order

16
00:00:44.148 --> 00:00:46.374
to really good idea of where
we're going and what can do.

17
00:00:46.374 --> 00:00:51.108
So I thought a little bit of history about
Kali Linux would maybe help us out here.

18
00:00:51.108 --> 00:00:52.361
Plus it's interesting,
it's fun stuff, right?

19
00:00:52.361 --> 00:00:53.340
>> It's very interesting, yes it is.

20
00:00:53.340 --> 00:00:54.600
>> It's good stuff, so.

21
00:00:54.600 --> 00:00:56.780
>> Especially the tassy with hearts.

22
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:58.980
>> [LAUGH] And
we'll actually come back to that too.

23
00:00:58.980 --> 00:01:02.190
We will talk about Kali and
where that comes from as well.

24
00:01:02.190 --> 00:01:06.779
So we talk about Kali Linux,
obviously it's a Linux distribution, but

25
00:01:06.779 --> 00:01:09.199
it's a special Linux distribution.

26
00:01:09.199 --> 00:01:14.750
It's really designed to be
a penetration testing platform.

27
00:01:14.750 --> 00:01:18.340
And when we say it's designed to
be a penetration testing platform,

28
00:01:18.340 --> 00:01:19.900
what does that mean?

29
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:24.080
Really, it's all about the tools that
come pre-installed on this distribution.

30
00:01:24.080 --> 00:01:27.135
That's one of the big
drawing points to Kali Linux,

31
00:01:27.135 --> 00:01:30.050
is all these tools are available
that you can go and

32
00:01:30.050 --> 00:01:34.232
install on whatever distribution of
Linux that you wanna run, right?

33
00:01:34.232 --> 00:01:37.737
But I can go and out and
I can download an image of Kali Linux,

34
00:01:37.737 --> 00:01:42.455
and I can have most of the tools that
I need pre-installed, ready to go.

35
00:01:42.455 --> 00:01:45.345
>> Who would benefit from
having this installation?

36
00:01:45.345 --> 00:01:49.985
>> Anybody that does penetration
testing or any type of security work.

37
00:01:49.985 --> 00:01:52.714
There's several options as far
as running Kali Linux goes,

38
00:01:52.714 --> 00:01:54.648
we're gonna go through several of those.

39
00:01:54.648 --> 00:01:59.376
Like being able to run them off of a live,
we'll say CD or DVD, but that doesn't

40
00:01:59.376 --> 00:02:03.990
happen too much anymore, we'll say
USB drive is probably more likely.

41
00:02:03.990 --> 00:02:08.260
But being able to have my pen testing
platform with me all the time on a thumb

42
00:02:08.260 --> 00:02:13.210
drive that I can boot up at any time from
any machine is a fantastic capability.

43
00:02:14.370 --> 00:02:17.289
Also the fact, and like I said,
you can get these tools and

44
00:02:17.289 --> 00:02:19.564
install them in just
about any Linux distro.

45
00:02:19.564 --> 00:02:22.904
But the fact is that our pre-compiled,
it's there,

46
00:02:22.904 --> 00:02:27.734
they're very controlling about what is
allowed to go into the repositories.

47
00:02:27.734 --> 00:02:29.406
It all has to be signed,

48
00:02:29.406 --> 00:02:34.100
we wanna make sure that our platform
is stable and safe and secure.

49
00:02:34.100 --> 00:02:39.110
And that's one of the advantages that
we get of running this particular

50
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:40.520
distribution of Linux.

51
00:02:40.520 --> 00:02:43.830
>> Now this sounds like Kali Linux is
very portable, and you mentioned USB,

52
00:02:43.830 --> 00:02:45.980
is that the only way you can transport it?

53
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:50.256
>> No, we'll show you several options
as far as running it from a USB.

54
00:02:50.256 --> 00:02:54.850
I'll show you how to make it from Windows,
from Linux, and we'll talk about Mac.

55
00:02:54.850 --> 00:02:58.560
I probably won't do it, but it's very
similar to doing it with Linux as well.

56
00:02:58.560 --> 00:03:03.060
But we could also run it in a VM, which
is another very common way to run Linux.

57
00:03:03.060 --> 00:03:05.120
Not quite as portable, right?

58
00:03:05.120 --> 00:03:07.770
But it's an easy way to
have an installation

59
00:03:07.770 --> 00:03:10.020
of Kali quickly available
when you need it.

60
00:03:10.020 --> 00:03:14.285
If you're primarily a Windows person for
your day-to-day job duties, but

61
00:03:14.285 --> 00:03:16.511
you need to pull up Kali once in a while.

62
00:03:16.511 --> 00:03:20.164
The VM, virtual machine,
might be the option you wanna go.

63
00:03:20.164 --> 00:03:21.600
Or dual boot, right,

64
00:03:21.600 --> 00:03:26.140
we can install it on side-by-side
with our Windows installation.

65
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:28.643
And I'll show you how to do that,
and that way you've got a permanent,

66
00:03:28.643 --> 00:03:31.304
you've just got reboot your system and
pick which one you wanna boot into.

67
00:03:31.304 --> 00:03:34.936
>> All right, we were talking about
dual boot on a becoming a Linux system

68
00:03:34.936 --> 00:03:37.620
administrator in another
episode with Don Pezet.

69
00:03:37.620 --> 00:03:40.240
So let's talk about
the history of Kali Linux.

70
00:03:40.240 --> 00:03:41.610
>> All right so-
>> Kalia, Kalima.

71
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:45.890
>> Yeah, Kalima, it's Debian based now.

72
00:03:45.890 --> 00:03:50.551
It wasn't back in the day, but
we'll say one, as far as Kali itself,

73
00:03:50.551 --> 00:03:55.270
designed for digital forensics and
penetration testing.

74
00:03:55.270 --> 00:03:59.028
Maintained and funded by a group called
Offensive Security, most of you out there

75
00:03:59.028 --> 00:04:02.203
are probably familiar with them and
their wonderful site they have.

76
00:04:02.203 --> 00:04:06.100
And all the training that they provide and
a lot of great resources there.

77
00:04:06.100 --> 00:04:11.244
Core developers just to give everybody
credit, and I apologize if I mispronounce

78
00:04:11.244 --> 00:04:16.890
these names, Mati Aharoni,
Devon Kearns, and Raphael Hertzog.

79
00:04:16.890 --> 00:04:20.640
Those are the three core developers,
but obviously there's several people

80
00:04:20.640 --> 00:04:25.360
that help maintain Kali, but they list
those guys out as their core developers.

81
00:04:25.360 --> 00:04:28.940
And as I said, for installation options,
install it on a hard disk,

82
00:04:28.940 --> 00:04:33.480
boot it from a live CD,
USB, do a virtual machine.

83
00:04:33.480 --> 00:04:36.920
But for the history, we'll say that one,

84
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:40.790
Offensive Security puts this out,
it came out in 2013.

85
00:04:40.790 --> 00:04:45.690
It's Debian-based as of now, but as I
think Ryan put in our chat room there,

86
00:04:45.690 --> 00:04:50.060
he knows his history as well, he mentioned
one called WHAX, and even Whoppix,

87
00:04:50.060 --> 00:04:52.100
before that BackTrack.

88
00:04:52.100 --> 00:04:55.850
So if we wanna follow the timeline,

89
00:04:55.850 --> 00:05:00.679
a long time ago there was a couple
distributions called WHAX and

90
00:05:00.679 --> 00:05:05.450
Woppx, and another one called
Auditor Security Collection.

91
00:05:05.450 --> 00:05:10.746
And these were great Linux distributions,
WHAX was Slack-based, very minimalistic.

92
00:05:10.746 --> 00:05:15.403
Auditor Security Collection was
a live CD that was KOPPIX-based,

93
00:05:15.403 --> 00:05:21.950
had 300 tools pre-compiled in there, and
there was some overlap between those two.

94
00:05:21.950 --> 00:05:26.106
So what they did, that's really
where BackTracks got its inception,

95
00:05:26.106 --> 00:05:29.292
was from combining or
kind of taking the best of WHAX and

96
00:05:29.292 --> 00:05:32.907
Auditor Security Collection,
and putting those together.

97
00:05:32.907 --> 00:05:38.223
And so BackTracks, for a long time was
one of the security distros to get.

98
00:05:38.223 --> 00:05:41.965
I remember playing with that and
using it, wow,

99
00:05:41.965 --> 00:05:47.830
this comes with all these tools already
built in here, it was fantastic.

100
00:05:47.830 --> 00:05:52.210
Well, back in 2012 the developers at
Offensive Security, and the developers

101
00:05:52.210 --> 00:05:56.640
that were working on BackTracks really
decided they wanted to kinda redo things.

102
00:05:56.640 --> 00:06:01.270
They wanted to add a bunch of new
features and capabilities, but

103
00:06:01.270 --> 00:06:05.130
realized that it was gonna require
a lot of re-work under the hood.

104
00:06:05.130 --> 00:06:09.630
And they decided that this would be just
a good time to kinda start over, and

105
00:06:09.630 --> 00:06:10.850
they switched over to Debian.

106
00:06:10.850 --> 00:06:14.055
In fact I want to say the last guy
they brought in, Raphael Hertzog,

107
00:06:14.055 --> 00:06:16.934
I wanna say he was their Debian
guru guy that they brought in.

108
00:06:16.934 --> 00:06:22.590
But that what's happened there,
is they switched over to Debian.

109
00:06:22.590 --> 00:06:28.850
The first official release of Kali was
in 2013, is when we had our first one.

110
00:06:28.850 --> 00:06:32.480
So BackTracks evolved into Kali Linux.

111
00:06:33.480 --> 00:06:38.510
So that's a little bit about the history,
and then as we've been alluding to

112
00:06:38.510 --> 00:06:42.132
a few times, and Zack has talked about the
name, it's always something that comes up.

113
00:06:42.132 --> 00:06:43.834
>> [LAUGH]
>> It probably doesn't have a lot to

114
00:06:43.834 --> 00:06:47.245
functionality-wise but hey, you know you
want to be able to talk intelligently.

115
00:06:47.245 --> 00:06:51.060
And you get out there, and
people are like Kali, Kalima, right?

116
00:06:51.060 --> 00:06:54.750
Think of Indiana Jones and
things like that.

117
00:06:54.750 --> 00:06:56.930
But if we take a look,
in fact let's go out and

118
00:06:56.930 --> 00:07:01.440
look at Kali's website here,
this is Kali.org.

119
00:07:01.440 --> 00:07:03.585
This is where we're gonna
be able to get the ISOs or

120
00:07:03.585 --> 00:07:05.180
whatever else we need to install it.

121
00:07:05.180 --> 00:07:09.670
You get a lot of information here,
they've got their official documentation.

122
00:07:09.670 --> 00:07:14.940
They've got a great community
that you can be a part of.

123
00:07:14.940 --> 00:07:19.195
Offensive Security, again, was the ones
that helped maintain and fund all of this.

124
00:07:19.195 --> 00:07:25.900
And then as far as, I went back and
found one of their pages in their history.

125
00:07:25.900 --> 00:07:29.449
This is an old page, this is from 2012,
back when Kali was released,

126
00:07:29.449 --> 00:07:31.754
it actually came official I think in 2013.

127
00:07:31.754 --> 00:07:34.997
But it talks about what I
was just talking about,

128
00:07:34.997 --> 00:07:39.900
how they scrapped it all and
started fresh, Ubuntu versus Debian.

129
00:07:39.900 --> 00:07:41.660
But down here,
I thought I'd point this out,

130
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:44.800
since we love to talk about this,
what's in a name?

131
00:07:44.800 --> 00:07:46.040
Hindu goddess of time and

132
00:07:46.040 --> 00:07:49.305
change, Philippine martial art,
cool word in Swahili.

133
00:07:49.305 --> 00:07:51.105
>> [LAUGH]
>> None of the above,

134
00:07:51.105 --> 00:07:54.561
Kali is simply a name we came up with for
our new distribution.

135
00:07:54.561 --> 00:07:57.702
So there you go,
straight from the horses mouth.

136
00:07:57.702 --> 00:08:01.413
It really doesn't mean anything,
it's just a word that they [CROSSTALK].

137
00:08:01.413 --> 00:08:06.370
>> But I intend to think they so
that movie within [INAUDIBLE].

138
00:08:06.370 --> 00:08:10.692
>> [CROSSTALK] I mean maybe that works out
good for us because now I can, in my mind,

139
00:08:10.692 --> 00:08:12.722
I can think of it as coming from that,

140
00:08:12.722 --> 00:08:16.143
they can do goddess
>> Somebody else might have a different

141
00:08:16.143 --> 00:08:16.830
opinion.

142
00:08:16.830 --> 00:08:18.650
And hey, they don't disagree with us, so

143
00:08:18.650 --> 00:08:22.905
hey, we can kind of have our own
truth maybe there if that works.

144
00:08:22.905 --> 00:08:29.280
[LAUGH] All right, so a little bit about
the history of Kali, where it came from.

145
00:08:29.280 --> 00:08:31.610
Again, it's one of
the popular distributions,

146
00:08:31.610 --> 00:08:33.480
if you are going to be doing pen testing.

147
00:08:33.480 --> 00:08:35.890
Any type of security
work because of the fact,

148
00:08:35.890 --> 00:08:39.230
that it is, its got all of the tools,
free compiler that is installed in there,

149
00:08:39.230 --> 00:08:42.680
the repositories are available
with with additional tools.

150
00:08:42.680 --> 00:08:46.880
They keep tight control over what is
getting added to their repositories,

151
00:08:46.880 --> 00:08:50.330
in fact they will tell you if you
go to their documentation in here

152
00:08:50.330 --> 00:08:53.480
one of the things that people are tempted
to do is add additional repositories so

153
00:08:53.480 --> 00:08:55.240
they can go get these other tools.

154
00:08:55.240 --> 00:08:58.330
And there's nothing wrong with that, but
just understand that you are reducing

155
00:08:58.330 --> 00:09:01.340
the security that's built
in to Kali by doing that.

156
00:09:01.340 --> 00:09:02.130
>> You open the door.

157
00:09:02.130 --> 00:09:04.860
>> Yes, they keep a tight
control over their repository.

158
00:09:04.860 --> 00:09:08.170
As you start adding other repositories,
now it's beyond their control and

159
00:09:08.170 --> 00:09:11.080
you can introduce things and
introduce instability or

160
00:09:11.080 --> 00:09:14.800
insecurity, which maybe is what you
want and you're okay with that.

161
00:09:14.800 --> 00:09:18.060
Or if you're trying to
keep it buttoned down and

162
00:09:18.060 --> 00:09:21.060
secure, stick with your
official repositories for Kali.

163
00:09:21.060 --> 00:09:23.430
>> And the cost for it is zero?

164
00:09:23.430 --> 00:09:24.210
>> It is zero.

165
00:09:24.210 --> 00:09:27.830
It is one of our favorite
price points here at IRProTV.

166
00:09:27.830 --> 00:09:28.950
The cost is free and

167
00:09:28.950 --> 00:09:32.500
you read on their website that you
will never have to pay for Kali Linux.

168
00:09:32.500 --> 00:09:38.220
Their intention is to keep it free
forever, which is a good thing.

169
00:09:38.220 --> 00:09:40.060
We like free around here.

170
00:09:40.060 --> 00:09:41.570
All right, now requirement-wise.

171
00:09:41.570 --> 00:09:43.010
And you can kill the screen feed here.

172
00:09:43.010 --> 00:09:44.350
Well, actually, you know what?

173
00:09:44.350 --> 00:09:46.570
I can go over and well,
I'll show you this.

174
00:09:46.570 --> 00:09:48.100
Let's go over to the Kali documentation.

175
00:09:48.100 --> 00:09:49.090
Sorry, Megan.

176
00:09:49.090 --> 00:09:50.050
Goof on you up there.

177
00:09:51.070 --> 00:09:55.100
Let's take a look at some of
the installation requirements.

178
00:09:55.100 --> 00:09:56.840
So I know it's a little bit small.

179
00:09:56.840 --> 00:09:57.820
I can zoom in for you.

180
00:09:57.820 --> 00:10:02.560
Minimum of 20 gigs hard space,
disk space for the Kali Linux install.

181
00:10:02.560 --> 00:10:04.920
If you're gonna be installing it,
on a hard drive right.

182
00:10:04.920 --> 00:10:07.580
If you're running it from a thumb drive or
something like that.

183
00:10:07.580 --> 00:10:10.400
Obviously this requirement
doesn't apply to you.

184
00:10:10.400 --> 00:10:13.660
RAM for I3 to 6 and 64-bit architecture,

185
00:10:13.660 --> 00:10:17.480
minimum one gigabyte,
recommended 2 gigabytes or more.

186
00:10:17.480 --> 00:10:21.720
And just like any operating system they
will tell I can run with 1 gigabyte and

187
00:10:21.720 --> 00:10:27.290
that's all you got we'll make it work,
but it's not gonna be painless.

188
00:10:27.290 --> 00:10:29.420
It gonna have to be a little slow
especially depending on what

189
00:10:29.420 --> 00:10:32.540
you are running, so
as the application once you get booted up.

190
00:10:32.540 --> 00:10:37.080
2 gigs recommended but just like
any other OS the more we through at

191
00:10:37.080 --> 00:10:40.310
it up to a certain point anyway that
you get the diminishing returns but

192
00:10:40.310 --> 00:10:42.290
up to a certain point we wanna
input more memory in there.

193
00:10:42.290 --> 00:10:45.170
Cuz when we are loading things
like password crackers or

194
00:10:45.170 --> 00:10:48.790
other things that might be CPU intensive
that need to store a lot of info in RAM

195
00:10:50.200 --> 00:10:51.710
better have in more memory.

196
00:10:51.710 --> 00:10:52.770
So the more you can do it the better.

197
00:10:54.790 --> 00:11:01.290
Or CD drive, DVD drive, or USB boot
support to get it installed, all right.

198
00:11:01.290 --> 00:11:06.220
Other than that, pretty slight
really when it comes to language.

199
00:11:06.220 --> 00:11:07.650
It's like most Linux distros,

200
00:11:07.650 --> 00:11:10.940
I mean they're pretty light
on their system requirements.

201
00:11:10.940 --> 00:11:14.970
Just keep in mind, different tools that
you run also have requirements and

202
00:11:14.970 --> 00:11:16.380
you're gonna have to add those up, so

203
00:11:16.380 --> 00:11:19.820
if you're planning on doing a lot of
multitasking or running any of those

204
00:11:19.820 --> 00:11:24.290
disks or memory-intensive applications or
anything like that, you'll have to

205
00:11:24.290 --> 00:11:27.480
think about that when you're specing out
your system that you wanna run this on.

206
00:11:27.480 --> 00:11:30.600
>> Now are you gonna have to download
additional software to manage

207
00:11:30.600 --> 00:11:33.230
the Kali Linux or is it all unto itself?

208
00:11:33.230 --> 00:11:34.310
>> No, it's all unto itself.

209
00:11:34.310 --> 00:11:36.700
So let's take a look at
their download page.

210
00:11:36.700 --> 00:11:38.790
In fact, let me jump back here.

211
00:11:38.790 --> 00:11:40.480
And downloading Kali Linux.

212
00:11:40.480 --> 00:11:45.040
So, when you go out there and
you decide that you wanna run Kali,

213
00:11:45.040 --> 00:11:48.920
you've got your choices of how you're
gonna go about running it, and

214
00:11:48.920 --> 00:11:53.570
then that will determine really what it
is that you're going to be downloading.

215
00:11:53.570 --> 00:11:56.410
Platform wise,
which I haven't mentioned yet, wide open,

216
00:11:56.410 --> 00:11:59.740
I mean there are 32 bit or
64 bit architecture.

217
00:11:59.740 --> 00:12:05.520
They even have a branch dedicated to ARM,
they have their

218
00:12:05.520 --> 00:12:10.980
NetHunter which is dedicated to running on
Android devices, really cool option there.

219
00:12:10.980 --> 00:12:14.790
You can go ahead and
get like a little, an older Nexus or

220
00:12:14.790 --> 00:12:17.340
certain Galaxy, certain Samsungs.

221
00:12:17.340 --> 00:12:18.540
The one, what is it?

222
00:12:18.540 --> 00:12:21.400
I forgot the name of that darn phone.

223
00:12:21.400 --> 00:12:23.970
The OnePlus One is another
one besides the Nexus.

224
00:12:23.970 --> 00:12:27.550
Nexus like 5 through Nexus 10,
these were NetHunter.

225
00:12:27.550 --> 00:12:32.880
This is for, basically it's
a version of Kali designed to run on

226
00:12:32.880 --> 00:12:36.010
this Android devices give you
a mobile platform, really cool.

227
00:12:36.010 --> 00:12:40.100
Now what we're gonna go and
do here is we're gonna stick with

228
00:12:40.100 --> 00:12:43.580
Kali Linux this one but wanted to make
sure you're aware they are available.

229
00:12:43.580 --> 00:12:49.220
It is just incredible like I know they can
run on things like a lot of your single

230
00:12:49.220 --> 00:12:53.470
board computers, like your BeagleBones,
and your Raspberry Pi is a big one.

231
00:12:53.470 --> 00:12:56.950
They've got a distro designed
to run on Raspberry Pi, so

232
00:12:56.950 --> 00:12:58.520
you can make headless units.

233
00:12:58.520 --> 00:13:02.120
They're talking about running
drones with these things.

234
00:13:02.120 --> 00:13:05.410
All kinds of neat stuff
you can do with Kali.

235
00:13:05.410 --> 00:13:07.920
So lots of options there.

236
00:13:07.920 --> 00:13:12.480
Now, as far as,
Zach you're asking about downloading it,

237
00:13:12.480 --> 00:13:16.110
one of the things you want to do is make
sure you're getting an official distro.

238
00:13:16.110 --> 00:13:21.750
Which means going to kali.org and
downloading it from there.

239
00:13:21.750 --> 00:13:25.540
Let me switch back to the main page here,
not the documentation.

240
00:13:25.540 --> 00:13:27.820
When you go to their main page,
and I'll do that again.

241
00:13:27.820 --> 00:13:30.660
Right on their main page you
got downloads up to the top.

242
00:13:30.660 --> 00:13:33.880
You can see download Kali Linux NetHunter.

243
00:13:33.880 --> 00:13:35.170
They got their release information.

244
00:13:35.170 --> 00:13:38.310
You can also click on the wonderful link
down here in the middle of the page.

245
00:13:38.310 --> 00:13:41.743
Either way it's gonna take you
over the Kali Linux distros.

246
00:13:41.743 --> 00:13:43.892
Here you're gonna decide
what it is you want.

247
00:13:43.892 --> 00:13:47.529
You got 32 and 64 bit Kali distributions.

248
00:13:47.529 --> 00:13:52.887
Got a light version, which is you
can see the image is a lot smaller,

249
00:13:52.887 --> 00:13:56.910
doesn't have nearly
the tools built into it.

250
00:13:56.910 --> 00:13:59.000
You'd be on your own, but
if you needed something smaller and

251
00:13:59.000 --> 00:14:02.500
you just needed certain tools
maybe that's the way you wanna go.

252
00:14:02.500 --> 00:14:06.920
A few different versions for,
with the different desktops enabled.

253
00:14:06.920 --> 00:14:10.510
Which is something you can actually
customize, but it's nice that you can pre

254
00:14:10.510 --> 00:14:13.750
or download one that's pre-configured
to use the desktop that you would like,

255
00:14:13.750 --> 00:14:16.240
the desktop manager you wanna use.

256
00:14:16.240 --> 00:14:21.560
As we scroll down further we get
down into our pre-built VMs.

257
00:14:21.560 --> 00:14:26.100
Virtualization, right, this is a great
way to get your feet wet in Kali Linux.

258
00:14:26.100 --> 00:14:29.610
Most of us are gonna have some type
of virtualization software available.

259
00:14:29.610 --> 00:14:33.540
And Offensive Security has created
these virtual hard drives,

260
00:14:33.540 --> 00:14:37.490
these pre-built virtual machines
that we can simply download and run.

261
00:14:37.490 --> 00:14:39.460
>> And that is good for
practice you think?

262
00:14:39.460 --> 00:14:40.620
Would you recommend that?

263
00:14:40.620 --> 00:14:44.445
>> Yeah absolutely, this is probably
the easiest way to get started.

264
00:14:44.445 --> 00:14:47.635
If you are not sure that
you want to use Kali or

265
00:14:47.635 --> 00:14:52.085
just want to see what it's about,
see if it's something you could use, and

266
00:14:52.085 --> 00:14:55.665
you've got virtualization software
available, this is probably the way to go.

267
00:14:55.665 --> 00:14:58.575
Because I don't have to install anything,
it's all done.

268
00:14:58.575 --> 00:15:02.465
I just fire up the virtual machine and
it's there and if you're newer to Linux,

269
00:15:02.465 --> 00:15:05.445
the installation process can be
a little bit confusing sometimes.

270
00:15:06.560 --> 00:15:08.935
Although it is much simpler
than it was years ago.

271
00:15:08.935 --> 00:15:11.465
[LAUGH]
>> Back in the day.

272
00:15:11.465 --> 00:15:17.370
>> [LAUGH] But now, like I said, this is
probably one of the easiest way to go.

273
00:15:17.370 --> 00:15:19.580
You can see if I go over
to Kali virtual images

274
00:15:20.970 --> 00:15:24.880
I either get several different platforms
that they are going to support.

275
00:15:24.880 --> 00:15:28.830
I've got the Let's see,
here's my VMware images.

276
00:15:28.830 --> 00:15:33.430
So this is what I use, because I'm
running Workstation on my laptop.

277
00:15:33.430 --> 00:15:35.370
But I've also got VirtualBox images.

278
00:15:35.370 --> 00:15:37.430
So if you've got a free.

279
00:15:37.430 --> 00:15:40.160
VirtualBox is a free
virtualization software.

280
00:15:40.160 --> 00:15:42.460
So now I can get my
virtualization software and

281
00:15:42.460 --> 00:15:47.090
my Kali Linux pre-built hard drive for
it all for free.

282
00:15:47.090 --> 00:15:50.830
And they even have,
believe it or not, HyperV image.

283
00:15:50.830 --> 00:15:51.620
Isn't that nice of them?

284
00:15:51.620 --> 00:15:53.868
Usually Windows gets left out.

285
00:15:53.868 --> 00:15:56.132
HyperV is never considered.

286
00:15:56.132 --> 00:16:00.378
But the good folks over there at Offensive
Security Have created a Hyper-V drive

287
00:16:00.378 --> 00:16:00.882
as well.

288
00:16:00.882 --> 00:16:04.560
They most likely converted one but
hey, anyway, it works.

289
00:16:04.560 --> 00:16:08.080
I've downloaded it, I've thrown out
a Hyper-V server and it works just great.

290
00:16:08.080 --> 00:16:09.180
>> And the price is right.

291
00:16:09.180 --> 00:16:10.890
>> And the price is right.

292
00:16:10.890 --> 00:16:11.750
Exactly.

293
00:16:11.750 --> 00:16:15.180
They've got it for
your ARM hardware as well.

294
00:16:15.180 --> 00:16:20.060
Like I said they have support for
a lot of different devices.

295
00:16:21.110 --> 00:16:25.140
And then Kali NetHunter which is
their mobile penetration platform.

296
00:16:25.140 --> 00:16:29.500
But what were gonna be focusing in
on in this series is going to be

297
00:16:29.500 --> 00:16:30.980
our straight up Kali Linux.

298
00:16:30.980 --> 00:16:33.700
We'll take a look at some of
the different installation options.

299
00:16:33.700 --> 00:16:36.570
And once we get it installed it doesn't
matter whether I'm running it from

300
00:16:36.570 --> 00:16:38.690
a Live or a VMWare or what have you.

301
00:16:38.690 --> 00:16:41.280
The tools are gonna be the same,
except for persistence.

302
00:16:41.280 --> 00:16:44.050
That is something we'll
talk about as well.

303
00:16:44.050 --> 00:16:48.160
If you're running this from a live,
from a USB drive, right.

304
00:16:48.160 --> 00:16:52.490
It's great because hey, I can take
anybody's computer if it's available.

305
00:16:52.490 --> 00:16:55.200
I can throw in my thumb drive,
I can reboot and I can boot to Kali.

306
00:16:55.200 --> 00:16:57.670
And I can run Linux right there.

307
00:16:57.670 --> 00:17:01.060
Or run my Kali and have access to
all my tools from right there.

308
00:17:01.060 --> 00:17:02.820
So that's great, except for

309
00:17:02.820 --> 00:17:05.400
the fact that we don't have
any persistence there, right?

310
00:17:05.400 --> 00:17:09.910
Because when I shut that thing down or
when I unplug that USB drive what about

311
00:17:09.910 --> 00:17:14.660
logs maybe that I captured or reports
from tools I run and things like that.

312
00:17:14.660 --> 00:17:18.950
There is a way that you can set up
an additional partition on the thumb drive

313
00:17:18.950 --> 00:17:22.560
that has persistence,
that will allow you to write to that and

314
00:17:22.560 --> 00:17:26.180
save things like output from tools,
reports.

315
00:17:26.180 --> 00:17:28.720
So we will show you how to
build one of those as well.

316
00:17:30.490 --> 00:17:32.100
Where else was I going with that?

317
00:17:33.460 --> 00:17:36.730
So, yeah,
we'll take a look at how to do that also.

318
00:17:38.900 --> 00:17:40.200
What else do we talk about.

319
00:17:40.200 --> 00:17:45.481
Is that we talked about the supportive
platforms, feature-wise,

320
00:17:45.481 --> 00:17:51.225
like I said, over 600 pre-installed
penetration testing programs.

321
00:17:51.225 --> 00:17:53.330
Now, that right there is great.

322
00:17:53.330 --> 00:17:54.170
>> I do have a question.

323
00:17:54.170 --> 00:17:54.956
>> Yes.
>> How many

324
00:17:54.956 --> 00:17:55.670
programs-
>> [LAUGH]

325
00:17:55.670 --> 00:17:58.156
>> Never mind, go ahead.

326
00:17:58.156 --> 00:18:02.535
>> Yeah, that's 600 things that I
don't have to try to install, right.

327
00:18:02.535 --> 00:18:04.570
Now, I might not use but half of those.

328
00:18:04.570 --> 00:18:08.110
But yeah,
having choices is a wonderful thing,

329
00:18:08.110 --> 00:18:10.540
different tools work at different times,
we've all been there.

330
00:18:10.540 --> 00:18:13.120
If you've done any kind of security work,
testing work you know,

331
00:18:13.120 --> 00:18:16.070
sometimes one tool that worked great
before, doesn't work so well in this

332
00:18:16.070 --> 00:18:20.270
situation and you need something else or
you need to confirm results, right?

333
00:18:20.270 --> 00:18:24.440
That's another thing that having
multiple tools is a big aid in.

334
00:18:24.440 --> 00:18:27.730
One running one tool, getting a set
of results, running another tool.

335
00:18:27.730 --> 00:18:30.041
Getting same results is confirmation.

336
00:18:30.041 --> 00:18:32.933
That's proof that I can use
if we're ever prosecuting or

337
00:18:32.933 --> 00:18:35.490
if we have a need to
provide this evidence.

338
00:18:35.490 --> 00:18:39.612
And speaking of evidence,
remember we said that this is

339
00:18:39.612 --> 00:18:43.483
a penetration
testing/forensics distribution.

340
00:18:43.483 --> 00:18:46.230
Well what makes it
a forensics distribution?

341
00:18:46.230 --> 00:18:50.450
Well, because one of the boot
options is actually to boot live,

342
00:18:50.450 --> 00:18:52.820
which we've talked about already.

343
00:18:52.820 --> 00:18:57.342
It used to be, how can I explain this,
in Back Tracks, prior to Kali,

344
00:18:57.342 --> 00:19:01.540
right, so prior to 2012,
when in running Back Tracks.

345
00:19:01.540 --> 00:19:03.160
It had a forensics mode.

346
00:19:03.160 --> 00:19:06.850
When you went to boot Back Tracks
off of a live live USB or

347
00:19:06.850 --> 00:19:09.960
a disk, it had a forensics
mode that you could boot into.

348
00:19:09.960 --> 00:19:16.580
And what that did is it prevented that,
Back Tracks, from auto mounting.

349
00:19:16.580 --> 00:19:18.730
It basically disabled all auto mounting,
so

350
00:19:18.730 --> 00:19:21.950
it wouldn't automatically mount any hard
drives or anything else that it found

351
00:19:21.950 --> 00:19:25.360
in the physical hardware that you
are booting this live distro to.

352
00:19:26.960 --> 00:19:31.590
And it won't touch any of the hard
drives internally or the swap space or

353
00:19:31.590 --> 00:19:34.170
any of the paging systems or
anything like that.

354
00:19:34.170 --> 00:19:37.053
And the idea is,
because if we're doing forensics,

355
00:19:37.053 --> 00:19:40.010
I cannot modify that system
that I'm investigating.

356
00:19:40.010 --> 00:19:42.625
I have to be very,
very careful about that.

357
00:19:42.625 --> 00:19:46.735
And so having a distribution allows
me to boot up in a mode that says,

358
00:19:46.735 --> 00:19:49.695
hey I'm not gonna touch the system
in any way, make any changes.

359
00:19:49.695 --> 00:19:53.955
I'm not gonna touch the hard drive,
I'm not gonna auto mount anything else.

360
00:19:53.955 --> 00:19:55.378
I'm gonna leave it completely alone.

361
00:19:55.378 --> 00:19:57.395
It's a good thing and
they've included that in Kali.

362
00:19:57.395 --> 00:20:01.120
So in Back Tracks, it was forensics mode.

363
00:20:01.120 --> 00:20:05.010
In Kali Linux it's just called live, but
it means, again, it won't auto mount or

364
00:20:05.010 --> 00:20:05.810
anything like that.

365
00:20:05.810 --> 00:20:09.470
So great, great operating system.

366
00:20:09.470 --> 00:20:10.120
Where was I?

367
00:20:10.120 --> 00:20:15.370
Features, we talked about there's a ton of
tools that come available in Kali Linux.

368
00:20:15.370 --> 00:20:18.320
It's a supported platform for
the Metasploit framework.

369
00:20:18.320 --> 00:20:22.927
Anybody that's done anything in security,
pen testing, is familiar with Metasploit.

370
00:20:22.927 --> 00:20:27.594
It's a framework where we can build and
test and run exploits.

371
00:20:27.594 --> 00:20:30.518
And Kali Linux is a supported platform,

372
00:20:30.518 --> 00:20:35.510
which means I can get all of that
Metasploit up and running on my Kali.

373
00:20:35.510 --> 00:20:37.090
In fact, it's installed in there already.

374
00:20:39.000 --> 00:20:41.400
I say Kali a live mode.

375
00:20:41.400 --> 00:20:45.810
One thing I will say about that again,
auto mounting is disabled,

376
00:20:45.810 --> 00:20:50.774
doesn't touch internal hard drive or
swap space, but people in offensive

377
00:20:50.774 --> 00:20:55.795
security and something we should know
already, you must test it, right.

378
00:20:55.795 --> 00:21:00.275
They'll let you know hey, yes this is what
it does, it shouldn't do any of these.

379
00:21:00.275 --> 00:21:05.532
Do not go into a live active case and run
Kali for the first time in live mode and

380
00:21:05.532 --> 00:21:10.720
hope that it's not gonna touch anything or
modify anything, right?

381
00:21:10.720 --> 00:21:15.955
Test that out first outside of
an actual case to make sure.

382
00:21:15.955 --> 00:21:19.891
You have to verify all of that and
make sure that your particular scenario,

383
00:21:19.891 --> 00:21:22.760
you're gonna get the results
that you expect.

384
00:21:22.760 --> 00:21:28.010
You don't want to corrupt anything or
destroy any evidence by testing out your

385
00:21:28.010 --> 00:21:31.470
Kali live thumb drive on
active evidence of any kind.

386
00:21:31.470 --> 00:21:33.060
>> Trust, but verify.

387
00:21:33.060 --> 00:21:36.060
>> Trust, but verify, exactly right.

388
00:21:36.060 --> 00:21:36.810
All right.
Well, so

389
00:21:36.810 --> 00:21:41.760
that's a little bit about the history of
Linux, where it came from, why we want,

390
00:21:41.760 --> 00:21:47.110
did I say Kali, the history of Linux, the
history of Kali Linux, where it came from,

391
00:21:47.110 --> 00:21:52.620
what it's built for, the different options
that we have to install, our requirements.

392
00:21:52.620 --> 00:21:55.040
And so I think that'll do it for
this episode.

393
00:21:55.040 --> 00:21:58.260
When we come back, we'll actually take
a look at getting it installed and

394
00:21:58.260 --> 00:21:59.310
getting it up and running.

395
00:21:59.310 --> 00:22:01.260
>> Well, Mike you got me excited and
you did a great job.

396
00:22:01.260 --> 00:22:02.740
Thank you very, very much.

397
00:22:02.740 --> 00:22:06.930
So it's a history of Kali Linux as we
continue on with the series Kali Linux.

398
00:22:06.930 --> 00:22:08.180
And thanks for watching.

399
00:22:08.180 --> 00:22:11.410
And make sure you watch all
of the videos in that series.

400
00:22:11.410 --> 00:22:13.360
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

401
00:22:13.360 --> 00:22:15.750
Remember a good IT pro is always learning.

402
00:22:15.750 --> 00:22:16.730
I'm Zach Memos.

403
00:22:16.730 --> 00:22:17.520
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

404
00:22:17.520 --> 00:22:19.697
>> And we'll see you soon.

405
00:22:19.697 --> 00:22:25.282
[MUSIC]

406
00:22:25.282 --> 00:22:28.509
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Mike and Zach cover the requirements for needed for installation of Kali Linux, suggested thumb drive size, how to download Kali, how to verify the download, and using a VM with Kali.
episodes.title: Kali Bootable USB Drive

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what 'Persistence' is, how to add Persistence to a portable (thumb-drive) Kali Linux application, how to modify our applications, and what 'Parted' is.
episodes.title: Live with Persistence

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what 'Encryption' is, how to add Encryption to a Kali Linux Thumb Drive application with 'Persistence', how to modify our applications, and adding a 'Nuke' key for added security.
episodes.title: Live with Encrypted Persistence

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss what a Kali Linux VM is, where & how to obtain a Kali VM, using 'Offensive Security,' other virtualization platforms, variations of the Kali VM, installation of Kali VM, discussion of built in persistence in the Kali VM, and launching & using the Kali VM.
episodes.title: Kali Virtual Machine Images

episodes.description: Mike and Zach cover the use of Kali Linux now that install has been completed, virtual guest tools, how to update Kali, using 'Apt-Get' update, downloading newer versions of Kali, upgrading Kali, changing passwords, adding non-root users, sidebar options, and lock screen.
episodes.title: Post Installation Configuration

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss how to change host name, modify host name, DNS mapped to IP addresses, and other basic mods after installation of Kali Linux.
episodes.title: Post Installation Configuration Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Zach define 'Metasploit' and how to access it, 'Postgesql,' using Apache with Kali Linux, and what 'SSH' is.
episodes.title: Post Installation Configuration Part 3

episodes.description: Mike and Zach discuss how to get the Kali Box connected to networks, how to configure network adapters, accessing the GUI, using Shell, adding multiple network adapters, and how we get Kali to communicate with Vulnerable Machines (VM).
episodes.title: Network Configuration

episodes.description: Mike and Zach continue the discussion of using Kali Linux basic functionality, using the 'Menu,' locating files, using 'Which' & 'Find' functions, accessing 'History,' and how to clear history.
episodes.title: Navigating Kali Linux

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss and use netcat, one of the fundamental tools in Kali Linux.   Mike describes briefly it’s history and versatility as a tool.   He demonstrates the power of netcat to run a banner grab and tcp connections. He begins to describe the bind shell and reverse shell exploit.
episodes.title: Netcat Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue demonstrating the “swiss army knife of hacking tools.”  Mike demonstrates it’s ability to set up a connection with ease that allows the user to send commands across this connection.  He also shows how files can be transferred, regardless of whether they’re executable files or just a simple text file.  Lastly, he show the simple nature of using nCAT ( Nmap’s version of netcat) to create an encrypted connection.
episodes.title: Netcat Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike dive into another tool in Kali: Wireshark.  Mike describes the purpose and the basic filtering methodology of wireshark.  He distinguishes using capture and display filter.
episodes.title: Wireshark Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continues with Wireshark. Mike shows how to setup and use a capture filter and the results.  He also then differentiates the results by doing a display filter too.  Mike ends the episode with a tcp stream follow to show how wireshark can reassemble the packets into a logical data stream.
episodes.title: Wireshark Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at another Kali Linux tool tcpdump.  Mike explains that tcpdump can provide another way of seeing the traffic that is not as sophisticated as Wireshark but just as complex.  With tcpdump, we can do some of the same things as wireshark and even filter specific information within a packet to display packet level details.
episodes.title: Tcpdump Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce nmap.  Mike describes it’s particular usage and then the syntax options when choosing to run nmap.  He begins describing the syntax used with some of the different scan types, options, target specifications and port specifications too.
episodes.title: Nmap Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike finish looking at the basic functionality of the Nmap port/network scanner. Here they demonstrate performing common scan types like versioning(-sV), OS guessing(-O), ping sweeping(-sn), and using lists(-iL).
episodes.title: Nmap Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike attempt to solidify your Kali skills by applying them to real-world type scenarios. Here they will scan a server and use Kali along with pen testing methodology to exploit 2 known vulnerabilities with rlogin and vsftpd.
episodes.title: Test Your Skills

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show how to take advantage of a vulnerable system.  Mike demonstrates how to use the available tools like nmap to do a port scan to find the vulnernabiility.  He then shows how to use map scripts to take advantage of nfs misconfiguration.  He runs the rpcinfo script and the nfs-showzount script to exploit the vulnerable machine.  Lastly, he sets up an ssl cert for a hidden backdoor access back into that system.
episodes.title: Test Your Skills Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike dive into the passive information gathering tools.  Kali Linux provides many tools and some of them are really designed to help us to find out more about our target in penetration testing, according to Mike.  He demonstrates the use of whois, netcraft, theharvester and a brief glimpse of recon-ng.  All of these tools are designed to help us to gather publicly available information without notifying the target.
episodes.title: Passive Information Gathering

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look into active information gathering tools in Kali Linux.  Mike shows the powerful host command to find information served up by the target system.  He demonstrates multiple options with the host command.  Mike also demos a couple of other tools that can show a tremendous amount of helpful information for the pentester.
episodes.title: Active Information Gathering

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike demonstrate setting up and using recon-ng.  Mike shows how to get started with contact information.  Using the email address from a domain gathered through recon-ng, Mike shows some of the other data that can be gathered just based on the email address.  He demonstrates loading the module and running the module and showing the results.
episodes.title: Recon-ng

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue with using recon-ng.  Mike demonstrate some of the other modules within recon-ng.  He demonstrates how easily it leads the user to search and find more results from the results found.  Ultimately, Mike demonstrates a report that can be generated for ease of use!
episodes.title: Recon-ng Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show the vulnerability scanner nikto. Mike demonstrates its syntax and usage.  He shows how to find the vulnerabilities and find entries to help discover more information about the vulnerabilities discovered.
episodes.title: Nikto Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at another vulnerability tool: Sparta.  Mike explains that it has the ability to run multiple tools at once, that it can simplify information gathering and is customizable.  He demonstrates where to can customizes Sparta using the sparta.conf file.   He also runs the utility to show how to add the targets and review the results from the scan in Sparta.
episodes.title: Sparta Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue to work a with Sparta.  Mike shows how to save the output of the scan to a file.  This allows us to use this file at a later time or pass it to another person for use, says Mike.  He also shows how to manipulate the sparta.conf file to add an additional tool into the Sparta Interface.
episodes.title: Sparta Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss the basics of generating wordlists for password attacks.  Mike describes the use of wordlists and that the goal is to have the most refined wordlist rather than the most words in a wordlists.  He also mentions that refining these list can begin with the basic tools that include wordlists such as found in Kali.  He also uses cell to show how to generate a word list by using websites to help you; this is good when looking at  password attack against a particular company or industry sector.
episodes.title: Generating Wordlists

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue with wordlist generation using crunch.   Mike demonstrates the incredible options of this tool that allow you to create parameters for the wordlists you want to generate.  He also discusses it’s particular ability is truly useful when the proper parameters are provided and when the reconnaissance is done beforehand.
episodes.title: Generating Wordlists Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss the use of hashcat.  It allows you to manipulate the existing passwords by replacing characters, insert character, prepend and append characters to help you create another wordlist.  Mike shows and demonstrates how to use the options available to get the results needed!
episodes.title: Generating Wordlists Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Mike and Cherokee look how to use John the Ripper to crack passwords. Mike explains the various modes used such as wordlist, single crack and incremental. He also specifies the default mode order if no mode is specified. Lastly, they look at KoreLogic Rules to help streamline the cracking process.
episodes.title: John the Ripper

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Mike use the tool hashcat to crack passwords. Mike explains how to use built in charsets. They use bruteforce to find the hashes of three of the four passwords.
episodes.title: Hashcat

episodes.description: In this show, Mike and Cherokee continue using hashcat. They use rules to help mangle the passwords and streamline the cracking process, reducing the processing time.
episodes.title: Hashcat Part 2
